data.source: Household and village survey data collected by the World Bank and Indian researchers (1997-1998); supplementary use of 2001 Indian census data for irrigation metrics
data.wave_or_subset: Survey of 120 villages in 12 districts of Uttar Pradesh and 13 districts of Bihar; supplementary analysis using 2001 census irrigation data
data.unit_of_analysis: Household (for income and yield outcomes) and village (for caste dominance, irrigation market structure, instruments)
data.notes: Data contains both village-level and household-level variables including caste composition, land ownership, pump/tubewell ownership, water buyer/seller status, crop incomes and yields. No codebook or access link provided in the manuscript summary.

method.description: Empirical comparison of economic outcomes of low-caste households across villages classified by caste dominance (upper-caste dominated vs backward-agricultural-caste dominated). Uses descriptive comparisons, OLS regressions with controls (education, land, state/district fixed effects), interaction terms between water-buyer status and village caste dominance, and instrumental variables (2SLS) to address endogeneity in private water market participation. Identification strategy leverages historical land-settlement patterns and zamindari reform as plausibly exogenous determinants of village-level caste dominance. Robustness checks evaluate geographic distance, groundwater quality, tenancy and credit relations, and land quality.
steps: Assemble household and village survey data (120 villages, ~2,250 households) and classify villages by caste dominance based on land ownership.
Compute descriptive statistics comparing household characteristics, incomes, crop incomes, irrigation access and pump ownership across high-caste and low-caste dominated villages.
Estimate OLS regressions of agricultural/crop income and yields on indicators for low-caste village dominance controlling for household education, land ownership and state/district fixed effects.
Include interaction terms between household water-buyer status and low-caste village indicator to assess differential effects of water market participation by village caste composition.

Implement instrumental variables (2SLS) estimation to address endogeneity in private water market participation using village-level instruments (village access to natural water sources and village size).

Conduct robustness checks and alternative-specification tests including controlling for land quality, geographic distance, groundwater quality, tenancy and credit arrangements, and examine composition of pump owners and water transactions by caste.
Interpret results with respect to market efficiency, contract enforcement, and caste-based exclusion in groundwater markets.
method.models: Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regressions with controls and fixed effects; regression specifications with interaction terms; Instrumental Variables estimation using Two-Stage Least Squares (2SLS); village-level instruments (natural water access, village size).
method.outcome_variable: Primary: household agricultural/crop income and crop yields (also crop income per acre, total household income).
method.independent_variables: Primary: village-level low-caste (BAC) dominance indicator; household water-buyer status; interaction of water-buyer status and low-caste village indicator. Other key variables include pump/tubewell ownership and caste composition of pump owners.
method.control_variables: Household education/literacy, land ownership/land size, state and district fixed effects, land quality (in some specifications), household demographic controls (where included).

results.summary: Low-caste households experience substantially better agricultural outcomes when living in villages dominated by backward agricultural castes (BACs) compared to high-caste dominated villages. Differences are driven primarily by better access to irrigation via private groundwater markets in low-caste dominated villages and more effective within-caste water trade and contract enforcement. Descriptive statistics show much higher crop incomes and yields in low-caste dominated villages. Regression results (OLS and IV) indicate positive and statistically significant effects of low-caste village dominance on crop income and that the benefit is concentrated among water buyers in low-caste villages. Alternative explanations (geography, groundwater quality, tenancy, credit, land quality) do not account for the observed differences.
